Project abstract:
Project abstract:
Deep disagreements are generally understood as systematic and persistent disagreements rooted in contrary worldviews where there is no mutually
recognized method of resolution because disputants reason and analyze evidence using different frameworks and/or principles. Despite their centrality
to our life, it remains unclear how we ought to understand deep disagreements and their implications for moral progress. My research aims to fill this
lacuna by rethinking the study of deep disagreements with Wittgenstein. First, drawing on Wittgenstein’s views and philosophical method, I develop a
novel account of deep disagreements. Against existing theories of deep disagreements, I defend that it is a mistake to assume that the characteristics of
deep disagreements display a theoretical unity that can only be adequately explained by one true global theory. Instead, deep disagreements are
complex phenomena that are to be clarified by a variety of complementary local explanations. Second, I use this account of deep disagreements to
assess whether they can contribute to moral progress. Specifically, I study the challenges of, and the unique opportunities offered by, deep
disagreements to determine if there are any strategies for constructive dialogue that contribute to moral progress.
